content.description: Start up a left-leaning finger crack (crux) for about 15 feet to a perfect hand jam. Continue into some moderate offwidth and some final steep fists.
content.protection: The bottom takes 1” pro easily, the upper section takes up to 5”, and there are 2 bolts with chains at the top.
content.location:
On the north side of Citadel Crag, facing Plumbline Crag, this is the obvious finger-crack-to-chimney just right of

Stems and Weeds

.

content.description: On the north side of the formation is a left-facing ramp with a crack in the right side.  It's sometimes a bit mossy but stems well.
content.protection: You can see the whole crack which takes, as I recall, hand-sized stuff, but you can place about anything #3 BD or smaller. Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: It's on the north side and is the obvious dihedral.

content.description: This is an really nice, crimpy slab route just left of stems and weeds.  It goes up and left to an arete.  That's where the crux is, then up to a layback around a roof.  Onto the roof and zip on to the top.
content.protection: 7? draws plus those for the fixed anchor at the top.  You might take one extra; I don't recall exactly.
content.location: On the north side of the formation, just left of Stems and Weeds, the obvious dihedral.

content.description: This is a tight hands to fist crack that finishes on heads of the valley. The rock quality is not great, but there are some fun moves pulling through a bulge in the classic Vedauwoo style. It must have been done before, so if anyone has route information, please let me know.
content.protection: Hand-size cams and a #4 will work. You need to build an anchor for the second, so bring some stuff in the 0.3-#2 Camalot size, and nuts work as well.
content.location: Finishes on head of the valley, starts to the right of heads of the valley. Walkoff to the right.

content.description: This route takes the prominent dike system that diagonals right along the southeast face.  The start is the crux and is heady though a fixed stopper eases the groundfall potential.  Cruise through the two-move crux, and follow the line of bolts until the dike ends.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 1 fixed stopper, 1 pin, and 1 set of large stoppers.  Belay near a pin, walk off.

climbs.name: Da Gyps Route
climbs.fa: Shane Miller, Chris Murray, Ken Hilton

content.description:
Da Gyps Route requires Gypsy Beta skills. Start with surmounting a low roof goes up through four bolts to anchor of

Citadel Crack

.
content.protection: You will need some gear for the start. Also, if runout 5.9 is scary for you bring some finger-sized widgets for the middle.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Citadel Crack

.

content.description: The problem is very easy but the feature is Amazing.
content.location: This boulder is in-between Nautilus and Citadel. on the right side of the road as you are driving to the Citadel.

content.description: Great roof crack!  Follow the thin crack which diagonals up and to the right towards the roof.  Look out for face features on this section of the climb.  Climb up to and through the perfect hands roof, and into the hand crack above.  The crack then peters out before the next roof, forcing you to climb delicately.  After pulling the final roof scramble up the last 15 feet and set an anchor.
content.protection: Small stoppers/RPs through #3 Camalot.  Doubles in #0.5 to #2 Camalot could be helpful but not necessary.  After the crack peters out above the first roof, small stoppers will give you some protection.  There are several large blocks at the top which can be slung as a top anchor.  Walk off to the East (climber's right).
content.location: On the south face of Citadel Crag, look for the large fin/roof on the left end of the crag.
